{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Thomism}} [[File:Thomas Aquinas in Stained Glass crop.jpg|thumb|[[Thomas Aquinas]] ({{circa|1225}}–1274)]] {{Catholic philosophy}} '''Thomism''' is the philosophical school that arose as a legacy of the work and [[thought of Thomas Aquinas]] (1225–1274), philosopher, theologian, and [[Doctor of the church#Catholicism|Doctor of the Church]]. In philosophy, [[Thomas Aquinas|Aquinas]]' [[Works by Thomas Aquinas|disputed questions and commentaries]] on [[Aristotle]] are perhaps his most well-known works. In theology, his ''[[Summa Theologica]]'' is one of the most influential documents in [[Medieval philosophy#Theology|medieval theology]] and continues to be the central point of reference for the philosophy and theology of the [[Catholic Church]]. In the 1914 encyclical ''Doctoris Angelici''{{cite web |url=http://maritain.nd.edu/jmc/etext/doctoris.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-04 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090831110620/http://maritain.nd.edu/jmc/etext/doctoris.htm |archivedate=31 August 2009 |df=dmy-all }} Accessed 25 October 2012 [[Pope Pius X]] cautioned that the teachings of the Church cannot be understood without the basic philosophical underpinnings of Aquinas' major theses: {{quote|The capital theses in the philosophy of St. Thomas are not to be placed in the category of opinions capable of being debated one way or another, but are to be considered as the foundations upon which the whole science of natural and divine things is based; if such principles are once removed or in any way impaired, it must necessarily follow that students of the sacred sciences will ultimately fail to perceive so much as the meaning of the words in which the dogmas of divine revelation are proposed by the magistracy of the Church.[[Pope Pius X]], ''Doctoris Angelici'', 29 June 1914.}} The [[Second Vatican Council]] described Aquinas' system as the "Perennial Philosophy".[[Second Vatican Council]], ''[[Optatam Totius]]'' (28 October 1965) 15. ==Thomistic philosophy== ===General=== [[Thomas Aquinas]] believed that [[truth]] is to be accepted no matter where it is found. His doctrines draw from [[ancient Greek philosophy|Greek]], [[Roman philosophy|Roman]], [[Jewish philosophy|Jewish]], philosophers. Specifically, he was a [[Philosophical realism|realist]] (i.e., he, unlike the [[Philosophical skepticism|skeptics]], believed that the world can be known as it is). He largely followed [[Aristotelianism|Aristotelian]] terminology and [[metaphysics]], and wrote comprehensive [[commentaries on Aristotle]], often affirming [[Aristotle]]'s views with independent arguments. Aquinas respectfully referred to Aristotle simply as "the Philosopher".E.g., [http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1084.htm#article7 ''Summa Theologiæ'', Q.84, art.7.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091029234148/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1084.htm |date=29 October 2009 }}, where the ''sed contra'' is only a quote from [[Aristotle]]'s ''[[De anima]]''. He also adhered to some [[neoplatonism|neoplatonic]] principles, for example that "it is absolutely true that there is first something which is essentially being and essentially good, which we call God, ... [and that] everything can be called good and a being, inasmuch as it [[Theory of Forms|''participates'' in it by way of a certain assimilation]]..."{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1006.htm#article4 |title=''Summa'', I, Q.6, art.4 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111204142644/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1006.htm#article4 |archivedate=4 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }} ===24 Thomistic Theses=== With the decree ''Postquam sanctissimus'' of 27 July 1914,[http://vaxxine.com/hyoomik/aquinas/theses.eht ''Postquam sanctissimus''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070810225643/http://www.vaxxine.com/hyoomik/aquinas/theses.eht |date=10 August 2007 }}, Latin with English translation
See also [http://www.u.arizona.edu/~aversa/scholastic/24Thomisticpart2.htm P. Lumbreras's commentary on the 24 Thomistic Theses] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605055456/http://www.u.arizona.edu/~aversa/scholastic/24Thomisticpart2.htm |date=5 June 2011 }}. [[Pope Pius X]] declared that 24 theses formulated by "teachers from various institutions ... clearly contain the principles and more important thoughts" of Aquinas. Principal contributors to the Church's official statement of the "24 Theses" of Thomism include [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] philosopher and theologian [[Edouard Hugon]] of the [[Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas|Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas, ''Angelicum'']] and [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit]] philosopher theologian Guido Mattiussi of the [[Pontifical Gregorian University]]. ==== Ontology ==== {{See also|Ontology}}
  1. Potency and Act divide being in such a way that whatever is, is either [[Actus purus|pure act]], or of necessity it is composed of potency and [[Actus primus|act as primary]] and intrinsic principles.
  2. Since act is perfection, it is not limited except through a potency which itself is a capacity for perfection. Hence in any order in which an act is pure act, it will only exist, in that order, as a unique and unlimited act. But whenever it is finite and manifold, it has entered into a true composition with potency.
  3. Consequently, the one God, unique and simple, alone subsists in absolute being. All other things that participate in being have a nature whereby their being is restricted; they are constituted of essence and being, as really distinct principles.
  4. A thing is called a being because of "esse". God and creature are not called beings univocally, nor wholly equivocally, but analogically, by an analogy both of attribution and of proportionality.
  5. In every creature there is also a real composition of the subsisting subject and of added secondary forms, i.e. [[Accidental property|accidental]] forms. Such composition cannot be understood unless being is really received in an essence distinct from it.
  6. Besides the absolute accidents there is also the relative accident, relation. Although by reason of its own character relation does not signify anything inhering in another, it nevertheless often has a cause in things, and hence a real entity distinct from the subject.
  7. A [[spiritual creature]] is wholly simple in its essence. Yet there is still a twofold composition in the spiritual creature, namely, that of the essence with being, and that of the substance with accidents.
  8. However, the corporeal creature is composed of act and potency even in its very essence. These act and potency in the order of essence are designated by the names form and matter respectively.
==== Cosmology ==== {{See also|Cosmology (metaphysics)|l1=Cosmology}}
  1. Neither the matter nor the form have being of themselves, nor are they produced or corrupted of themselves, nor are they included in any category otherwise than reductively, as substantial principles.
  2. Although extension in quantitative parts follows upon a corporeal nature, nevertheless it is not the same for a body to be a substance and for it to be quantified. For of itself substance is indivisible, not indeed as a point is indivisible, but as that which falls outside the order of dimensions is indivisible. But quantity, which gives the substance extension, really differs from the substance and is truly an accident.
  3. The principle of individuation, i.e., of numerical distinction of one individual from another with the same specific nature, is matter designated by quantity. Thus in pure spirits there cannot be more than one individual in the same specific nature.
  4. By virtue of a body's quantity itself, the body is circumscriptively in a place, and in one place alone circumscriptively, no matter what power might be brought to bear.
  5. Bodies are divided into two groups; for some are living and others are devoid of life. In the case of the living things, in order that there be in the same subject an essentially moving part and an essentially moved part, the substantial form, which is designated by the name soul, requires an organic disposition, i.e. heterogeneous parts.
==== Psychology ==== {{See also|Psychology}}
  1. Souls in the vegetative and sensitive orders cannot subsist of themselves, nor are they produced of themselves. Rather, they are no more than principles whereby the living thing exists and lives; and since they are wholly dependent upon matter, they are incidentally corrupted through the corruption of the composite.
  2. On the other hand, the human soul subsists of itself. When it can be infused into a sufficiently disposed subject, it is created by God. By its very nature, it is incorruptible and immortal.
  3. This rational soul is united to the body in such a manner that it is the only substantial form of the body. By virtue of his soul a man is a man, an animal, a living thing, a body, a substance and a being. Therefore, the soul gives man every essential degree of perfection; moreover, it gives the body a share in the act of being whereby it itself exists.
  4. From the human soul there naturally issue forth powers pertaining to two orders, the organic and the non-organic. The organic powers, among which are the senses, have the composite as their subject. The non-organic powers have the soul alone as their subject. Hence, the intellect is a power intrinsically independent of any bodily organ.
  5. Intellectuality necessarily follows upon immateriality, and furthermore, in such manner that the further the distance from matter, the higher the degree of intellectuality. Any being is the adequate object of understanding in general. But in the present state of union of soul and body, quantities abstracted from the material conditions of individuality are the proper object of the human intellect.
  6. Therefore, we receive knowledge from sensible things. But since sensible things are not actually intelligible, in addition to the intellect, which formally understands, an active power must be acknowledged in the soul, which power abstracts intelligible likeness or species from sense images in the imagination.
  7. Through these intelligible likenesses or species we directly know universals, i.e. the natures of things. We attain to singulars by our senses, and also by our intellect, when it beholds the sense images. But we ascend to knowledge of spiritual things by analogy.
  8. The will does not precede the intellect but follows upon it. The will necessarily desires that which is presented to it as a good in every respect satisfying the appetite. But it freely chooses among the many goods that are presented to it as desirable according to a changeable judgment or evaluation. Consequently, the choice follows the final practical judgment. But the will is the cause of it being the final one.
==== God ==== {{See also|God}}
  1. We do not perceive by an immediate intuition that God exists, nor do we prove it ''[[a priori and a posteriori|a priori]]''. But we do prove it ''[[Empirical evidence|a posteriori]]'', i.e., from the things that have been created, following an argument from the effects to the cause: namely, from things which are moved and cannot be the adequate source of their motion, to a first unmoved mover; from the production of the things in this world by causes subordinated to one another, to a first uncaused cause; from corruptible things which equally might be or not be, to an absolutely necessary being; from things which more or less are, live, and understand, according to degrees of being, living and understanding, to that which is maximally understanding, maximally living and maximally a being; finally, from the order of all things, to a [[active intellect|separated intellect]] which has ordered and organized things, and directs them to their end.
  2. The metaphysical motion of the Divine Essence is correctly expressed by saying that it is identified with the exercised actuality of its own being, or that it is subsistent being itself. And this is the reason for its infinite and unlimited perfection.
  3. By reason of the very purity of His being, God is distinguished from all finite beings. Hence it follows, in the first place, that the world could only have come from God by creation; secondly, that not even by way of a miracle can any finite nature be given creative power, which of itself directly attains the very being of any being; and finally, that no created agent can in any way influence the being of any effect unless it has itself been moved by the first Cause.
== Metaphysics == Aquinas says that the fundamental [[axiom]]s of [[ontology]] are the [[principle of non-contradiction]] and the [[principle of causality]]. Therefore, any [[being]] that does not contradict these two laws could theoretically exist,[http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte&Essentia.htm ''De Ente et Essentia'', 67–68.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091126104033/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte%26Essentia.htm |date=26 November 2009 }} "Although everyone admits the simplicity of the First Cause, some try to introduce a composition of matter and form in the intelligences and in souls... But this is not in agreement with what philosophers commonly say, because they call them substances separated from matter, and prove them to be without all matter." even if said being were [[incorporeal]].{{cite web |url=http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/ContraGentiles2.htm#91 |title=''Summa contra Gentiles'', II, chp. 91 |publisher=Op-stjoseph.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228235648/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/ContraGentiles2.htm#91 |archivedate=28 February 2009 |df=dmy-all }} === Predication === Aquinas noted three forms of descriptive language when [[Predicate (grammar)|predicating]]: univocal, [[analogy|analogical]], and [[Equivocation|equivocal]].{{cite book | author = Sproul, R.C. | authorlink = R. C. Sproul | title = Renewing Your Mind: Basic Christian Beliefs You Need to Know | publisher = Baker Books | location = Grand Rapids, MI | year = 1998 | page = 33 | isbn = 978-0-8010-5815-8}} * '''Univocality''' is the use of a descriptor in the same sense when applied to two objects or groups of objects. For instance, when the word "milk" is applied both to milk produced by cows and by any other female mammal. * '''Analogy''' occurs when a descriptor changes some but not all of its meaning. For example, the word "healthy" is analogical in that it applies both to a healthy person or animal (those that enjoy of good health) and to some food or drink (if it is good for the health). * '''Equivocation''' is the complete change in meaning of the descriptor and is an [[informal fallacy]]. For example, when the word "bank" is applied to river banks and financial banks, modern philosophers talk of [[ambiguity]]. Further, the usage of "[[definition]]" that Aquinas gives is the [[genus]] of the being, plus a difference that sets it apart from the genus itself. For instance, the [[Aristotelianism|Aristotelian]] definition of "man" is "[[rational animal]]"; its genus being animal, and what sets apart man from other animals is his [[rationality]].{{cite web |url=http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte&Essentia.htm |title=''De Ente et Essentia'', 37 |publisher=Op-stjoseph.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091126104033/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte%26Essentia.htm |archivedate=26 November 2009 |df=dmy-all }} === Being === {{see also|Being#Thomistic analogical predication of being}} {{quote|[E]xistence is twofold: one is essential existence or the '''[[Substance theory|substantial]]''' existence of a thing, for example man exists, and this is existence ''simpliciter''. The other is '''[[Accident (philosophy)|accidental]]''' existence, for example man is white, and this is existence ''secundum quid''.|[http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DePrincNaturae.htm ''De Principiis Naturæ'', 1.]}} In Thomist philosophy, the definition of a [[being]] is "that which is," which is composed of two parts: "which" refers to its ''[[quiddity]]'' (literally "whatness"), and "is" refers to its ''esse'' (the [[Latin language|Latin]] [[infinitive]] [[verb]] "to be").[http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte&Essentia.htm ''De Ente et Essentia'', 83.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091126104033/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte%26Essentia.htm |date=26 November 2009 }} "And this is why substances of this sort are said by some to be composed of "that by which it is" and "that which is," or as Boethius says, of "that which is" and "existence."" "''Quiddity''" is synonymous with [[essence]], [[Theory of Forms|form]] and [[Nature (philosophy)|nature]]; whereas "''esse''" refers to the principle of the being's existence. In other words, a being is "an essence that exists."[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1003.htm#article4 ''Summa'', I, Q.3, art.4.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109160402/http://newadvent.org/summa/1003.htm |date=9 November 2011 }} "Therefore, if the existence of a thing differs from its essence, this existence must be caused either by some exterior agent or by its essential principles." Being is divided in two ways: that which is ''in itself'' ([[Substance theory|substances]]), and that which is ''in another'' ([[Accident (philosophy)|accidents]]). Substances are things which exist ''per se'' or in their own right. Accidents are qualities that apply to other things, such as shape or color: "[A]ccidents must include in their definition a subject which is outside their genus."{{cite web |url=http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte&Essentia.htm |title=''De Ente et Essentia'', 17 |publisher=Op-stjoseph.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091126104033/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte%26Essentia.htm |archivedate=26 November 2009 |df=dmy-all }} Because they only exist in other things, Aquinas holds that [[metaphysics]] is primarily the study of substances, as they are the primary mode of being.{{cite web |url=http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte&Essentia.htm |title=''De Ente et Essentia'', 110 |publisher=Op-stjoseph.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091126104033/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte%26Essentia.htm |archivedate=26 November 2009 |df=dmy-all }} "And because accidents are not composed of matter and form, their genus cannot be taken from matter and their difference from form, as in the case of composed substances." ''[[The Catholic Encyclopedia]]'' pinpoints Aquinas' definition of ''quiddity'' as "that which is expressed by its definition."{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/05543b.htm |title=Aveling, Francis. "Essence and Existence." The Catholic Encyclopedia. Vol. 5. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1909. 4 Nov. 2009 |publisher=Newadvent.org |date=1 May 1909 |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011221713/http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/05543b.htm |archivedate=11 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The ''quiddity'' or [[Theory of Forms|form]] of a thing is what makes the object what it is: "[T]hrough the form, which is the [[Potentiality and actuality|actuality]] of matter, matter becomes something actual and something individual,"{{cite web |url=http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte&Essentia.htm |title=''De Ente et Essentia'', 18 |publisher=Op-stjoseph.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091126104033/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte%26Essentia.htm |archivedate=26 November 2009 |df=dmy-all }} and also, "the form causes matter to be."[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1075.htm#article5 ''Summa'', I, Q.75, art.5.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119083516/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1075.htm |date=19 January 2012 }} The meaning of this sentence can be altered depending on how the Latin word used in this sentence, "materiæ", is translated into English. An alternate rendering of this sentence is "The form causes matter ''to be what it is''. Thus, it consists of two parts: "prime matter" (matter without form),{{cite web |url=http://dhspriory.org/thomas/DeEnte&Essentia.htm |title=''De Ente et Essentia'', 40 |publisher=Dhspriory.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111219234241/http://dhspriory.org/thomas/DeEnte%26Essentia.htm |archivedate=19 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }} and [[substantial form]], which is what causes a substance to have its characteristics. For instance, an animal can be said to be a being whose matter is its body, and whose [[Soul#Thomas Aquinas|soul]]The Aristotelian and Thomist definition of the "soul" does not refer to spirit, but is perhaps better translated as "life force." Hence, plants have souls in the sense that they are living beings. The human soul is unique in that it has consciousness. Cf. ''[[De anima]]'', Bk. I. is its substantial form.{{cite web |url=http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte&Essentia.htm |title=''De Ente et Essentia'', 14 |publisher=Op-stjoseph.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091126104033/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte%26Essentia.htm |archivedate=26 November 2009 |df=dmy-all }}[http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DePrincNaturae.htm ''De Principiis Naturæ'', 5.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090916155648/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DePrincNaturae.htm |date=16 September 2009 }} "But, just as everything which is in potency can be called matter, so also everything from which something has existence whether that existence be substantial or accidental, can be called form; for example man, since he is white in potency, becomes actually white through whiteness, and sperm, since it is man in potency, becomes actually man through the soul." Together, these consist of its ''quiddity''/essence. All real things have the [[Transcendentals|transcendental properties of being]]: [[wikt:unity|oneness]], [[truth]], goodness (that is, all things have a [[final cause]] and therefore a [[Teleology|purpose]]), etc.{{cite web |url=http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/QDdeVer1.htm |title=''De veritate'', Q.1 |publisher=Op-stjoseph.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090424063600/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/QDdeVer1.htm |archivedate=24 April 2009 |df=dmy-all }} === Causality === Aristotle categorized causality into [[Four causes|four subsets]] in the ''[[Metaphysics (Aristotle)|Metaphysics]]'', which is an integral part of Thomism: {{quote|"In one sense the term cause means (a) that from which, as something intrinsic, a thing comes to be, as the bronze of a statue and the silver of a goblet, and the genera of these. In another sense it means (b) the form and pattern of a thing, i.e., the intelligible expression of the ''quiddity'' and its genera (for example, the ratio of 2: 1 and number in general are the cause of an octave chord) and the parts which are included in the intelligible expression. Again, (c) that from which the first beginning of change or of rest comes is a cause; for example, an adviser is a cause, and a father is the cause of a child, and in general a maker is a cause of the thing made, and a changer a cause of the thing changed. Further, a thing is a cause (d) inasmuch as it is an end, i.e., that for the sake of which something is done; for example, health is the cause of walking. For if we are asked why someone took a walk, we answer, "in order to be healthy"; and in saying this we think we have given the cause. And whatever occurs on the way to the end under the motion of something else is also a cause. For example, reducing, purging, drugs and instruments are causes of health; for all of these exist for the sake of the end, although they differ from each other inasmuch as some are instruments and others are processes."|[http://dhspriory.org/thomas/Metaphysics5.htm#2 Metaphysics 1013a, trans. John P. Rowan, Chicago, 1961]}} :* (a) refers to the '''material cause''', what a being's matter consists of (if applicable). :* (b) refers to the '''formal cause''', what a being's essence is. :* (c) refers to the '''efficient cause''', what brings about the beginning of, or change to, a being. :* (d) refers to the '''final cause''', what a being's purpose is. Unlike many [[ancient Greek philosophy|ancient Greeks]], who thought that an [[infinite regress]] of causality is possible (and thus held that the universe is uncaused), Aquinas argues that an infinite chain never accomplishes its objective and is thus impossible.{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1044.htm#article1 |title=''Summa'', I, Q.44, art.1 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111105100607/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1044.htm#article1 |archivedate=5 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Hence, a [[first cause]] is necessary for the existence of anything to be possible. Further, the First Cause must continuously be in action (similar to how there must always be a first chain in a [[Chain-link fencing|chain link]]), otherwise the series collapses:{{cite web |url=http://dhspriory.org/thomas/Metaphysics5.htm |title=St. Thomas Aquinas's commentary on the ''Metaphysics'', Bk. V, 1015a 20-1015b 15, §840 |publisher=Dhspriory.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111119193820/http://dhspriory.org/thomas/Metaphysics5.htm |archivedate=19 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} {{quote|[[Aristotle|The Philosopher]] says ([http://dhspriory.org/thomas/Metaphysics2.htm#4 ''Metaph''. ii, 2]) that "to suppose a thing to be indefinite is to deny that it is good." But the good is that which has the nature of an end. Therefore it is contrary to the nature of an end to proceed indefinitely. Therefore it is necessary to fix one last end.|[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2001.htm#article4 ''Summa'', II-I, Q.1, art.4.]}} Thus, both Aristotle and Aquinas conclude that there must be an uncaused Primary Mover,{{cite web |url=http://dhspriory.org/thomas/Metaphysics2.htm#3 |title=St. Thomas Aquinas's commentary on the Metaphysics, Bk. II, 994a 11-994b 9 |publisher=Dhspriory.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111127020714/http://dhspriory.org/thomas/Metaphysics2.htm#3 |archivedate=27 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://dhspriory.org/thomas/ContraGentiles2.htm#15|title=''Summa contra Gentiles'', II, chp.15|author=|date=|website=dhspriory.org|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100903045031/http://dhspriory.org/thomas/ContraGentiles2.htm#15|archivedate=3 September 2010|df=dmy-all}}[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1002.htm#article3 ''Summa'', I, Q.2, art.3.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130428053715/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1002.htm |date=28 April 2013 }} "The third way is taken from possibility and necessity, and runs thus..." because an infinite regress is impossible.{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2001.htm#article4 |title=''Summa'', II-I, Q.1, art.4 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111105095827/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2001.htm#article4 |archivedate=5 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} However, the First Cause does not necessarily have to be temporally the first. Thus, the question of whether or not the universe can be imagined as eternal was fiercely debated in the [[Middle Ages]]. The [[Condemnations of 1210–1277|University of Paris's condemnation of 1270]] denounced the belief that the world is eternal. Aquinas' intellectual rival, [[Bonaventure]], held that the [[Temporal finitism|temporality]] of the universe is demonstrable by reason.[http://www.franciscan-archive.org/bonaventura/opera/bon02019.html Br. Bugnolo, Alexis, trans., Opera Omnia S. Bonaventurae (Franciscan Archives, 2007), 22.]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=SheriffIsInTown |fix-attempted=yes }} "It must be said, that to posit, that the world is eternal and (has) not (been) eternally produced, by positing that all things (have been) produced out of nothing, is entirely contrary to the truth and to reason."Davis, Richard. "Bonaventure and the Arguments for the Impossibility of an Infinite Temporal Regression." ''American Catholic Philosophical Quarterly'' 70, no. 3 (Summer 1996): 361 – 380. Poiesis: Philosophy Online, EBSCOhost (Retrieved 13 April 2010): 380. Aquinas' position was that the temporality of the world is an article of faith, and not demonstrable by reason; though one could reasonably conclude either that the universe is temporal or eternal.{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1046.htm#article2 |title=''Summa'', I, Q.46, art.2 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109160407/http://newadvent.org/summa/1046.htm#article2 |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://dhspriory.org/thomas/DeEternitateMundi.htm |title=''De aeternitate mundi'' |publisher=Dhspriory.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111204111751/http://dhspriory.org/thomas/DeEternitateMundi.htm |archivedate=4 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }} === Goodness === As per the ''[[Nicomachean Ethics]]'' of [[Aristotle]],{{cite web |url=http://dhspriory.org/thomas/Ethics1.htm |title=''Nicomachean Ethics'', Bk. I, Chp. I, 1094a4 |publisher=Dhspriory.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001211100/http://dhspriory.org/thomas/Ethics1.htm |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Aquinas defines "[[Value (ethics)|the good]]" as what all things strive for. E.g., a cutting knife is said to be good if it is effective at its function, cutting. As all things have a function/[[final cause]], all real things are good. Consequently, [[evil]] is nothing but ''[[privatio boni]]'', or "lack of good", as [[Augustine of Hippo]] defined it.[[Augustine of Hippo]]. [http://www.newadvent.org/fathers/1302.htm ''Enchridion'', chp. 11.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100109103333/http://www.newadvent.org/fathers/1302.htm |date=9 January 2010 }} {{quote|[[Pseudo-Dionysius|Dionysius]] says (Div. Nom. iv), 'Evil is neither a being nor a good.' I answer that, one opposite is known through the other, as darkness is known through light. Hence also what evil is must be known from the nature of good. Now, we have said above that good is everything appetible; and thus, since every nature desires its own being and its own perfection, it must be said also that the being and the perfection of any nature is good. Hence it cannot be that evil signifies being, or any form or nature. Therefore it must be that by the name of evil is signified the absence of good. And this is what is meant by saying that 'evil is neither a being nor a good.' For since being, as such, is good, the absence of one implies the absence of the other.|[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1048.htm#article1 ''Summa'', I, Q.48, art.1.]}} Commentating on the aforementioned, Aquinas says that "there is no problem from the fact that some men desire evil. For they desire evil only under the aspect of good, that is, insofar as they think it good. Hence their intention primarily aims at the good and only incidentally touches on the evil."{{cite web |url=http://dhspriory.org/thomas/Ethics1.htm#1 |title=St. Thomas Aquinas's commentary on the ''Nicomachean Ethics'', Bk. I, Lec. I, §10 |publisher=Dhspriory.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001211100/http://dhspriory.org/thomas/Ethics1.htm#1 |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }} As God is the ultimate end of all things,{{cite web |url=http://dhspriory.org/thomas/ContraGentiles3a.htm#18 |title=''Summa Contra Gentiles'', III, Q.18 |publisher=Dhspriory.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007222742/http://dhspriory.org/thomas/ContraGentiles3a.htm#18 |archivedate=7 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }} God is by essence goodness itself.{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1006.htm |title=''Summa'', I., Q.6., art.2 & 3 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111204142644/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1006.htm |archivedate=4 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Furthermore, since love is "to wish the good of another,"{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2026.htm#article4 |title=''Summa'', II-I, Q.26, art.4 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109213721/http://newadvent.org/summa/2026.htm#article4 |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} true love in Thomism is to lead another to God. Hence why [[John the Evangelist]] says, "Whoever is without love does not know God, for God is love."{{cite web |url=http://www.usccb.org/nab/bible/1john/1john4.htm |title=1 John 4:8 |publisher=Usccb.org |date=13 March 2011 |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110731155725/http://www.usccb.org/nab/bible/1john/1john4.htm |archivedate=31 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1020.htm#article1 |title=''Summa'', I, Q.20, art.1 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111115172453/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1020.htm#article1 |archivedate=15 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} === Existence of God === {{Main|Quinquae viae}} Thomas Aquinas holds that the [[existence of God]] can be demonstrated by reason,{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1002.htm |title=''Summa'', I, Q.2 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130428053715/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1002.htm |archivedate=28 April 2013 |df=dmy-all }} a view that is taught by the Catholic Church.''[[Catechism of the Catholic Church]]'', [http://www.vatican.va/archive/catechism/p1s1c1.htm CCC 34.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926223727/http://www.vatican.va/archive/catechism/p1s1c1.htm |date=26 September 2009 }} The ''quinque viae'' (Latin: '''five ways''') found in the ''[[Summa Theologica]]'' ([http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1002.htm#article3 I, Q.2, art.3]) are five possible ways of demonstrating the existence of God,Aquinas offers more metaphysical explanations for the existence of God in ''[http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte&Essentia.htm De Ente et Essentia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091126104033/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte%26Essentia.htm |date=26 November 2009 }}'' and elsewhere, though the ''Quinquae viae'' are the most well-known and most commonly analyzed among these. which today are categorized as: : 1. ''Argumentum ex motu'', or the argument of the [[unmoved mover]]; : 2. ''Argumentum ex ratione causae efficientis'', or the argument of the [[first cause]]; : 3. ''Argumentum ex contingentia'', or the [[Necessary being|argument from contingency]]; : 4. ''Argumentum ex gradu'', or the [[argument from degree]]; and : 5. ''Argumentum ex fine'', or the [[teleological argument]]. Despite this, Aquinas also thought that [[sacred mysteries]] such as [[the Trinity]] could only be obtained through [[revelation]]; though these truths cannot contradict reason: {{quote|The existence of God and other like truths about God, which can be known by natural reason, are not articles of faith, but are preambles to the articles; for faith presupposes natural knowledge, even as grace presupposes nature, and perfection supposes something that can be perfected. Nevertheless, there is nothing to prevent a man, who cannot grasp a proof, accepting, as a matter of faith, something which in itself is capable of being scientifically known and demonstrated.|[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1002.htm#article2 ''Summa'', I, Q.2, art.2.]}} Aquinas responds to the [[problem of evil]] by saying that God allows evil to exist that good may come of it,[http://dhspriory.org/thomas/ContraGentiles3a.htm#10 ''Summa Contra Gentiles'', Bk. III, Q.10.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007222742/http://dhspriory.org/thomas/ContraGentiles3a.htm |date=7 October 2011 }} "Thus, it is... that evil is only caused by good accidentally." (for goodness done out of free will is superior than goodness done from biological imperative) but does not personally cause evil Himself.{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1049.htm#article2 |title=''Summa'', I, Q.49, art.2 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109155603/http://newadvent.org/summa/1049.htm#article2 |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} See also [http://www.ewtn.com/library/theology/reality.htm#07 ''Reality: A Synthesis of Thomistic Thought'': Chapter 7: The Proofs Of God's Existence] by [[Reginald Garrigou-Lagrange]]. === View of God === Aquinas articulated and defended, both as a philosopher and a theologian, the orthodox Christian [[God in Christianity|view of God]]. God is the sole being whose [[existence]] is the same as His [[essence]]: "what subsists in God is His existence."{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1003.htm |title=''Summa'', I, Q.3, art.4 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109160402/http://newadvent.org/summa/1003.htm |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} (Hence why God names himself "[[I Am that I Am]]" in [http://www.newadvent.org/bible/exo003.htm Exodus 3:14].{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1013.htm#article11 |title=''Summa'', I, Q.13, art.11 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111120065531/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1013.htm#article11 |archivedate=20 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }}) Consequently, God cannot be a body (that is, He cannot be composed of [[matter]]),{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1003.htm#article1 |title=''Summa'', I, Q.13, art. 1 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109160402/http://newadvent.org/summa/1003.htm#article1 |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} He cannot have any [[Accident (philosophy)|accidents]],{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1003.htm#article6 |title=''Summa'', I, Q.13, art. 6 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109160402/http://newadvent.org/summa/1003.htm#article6 |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} and He must be [[Divine simplicity|simple]] (that is, not separated into parts; [[the Trinity]] is one [[Substance theory|substance]] in three persons).{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1003.htm#article7 |title=''Summa'', I, Q.13, art. 7 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109160402/http://newadvent.org/summa/1003.htm#article7 |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Further, He is [[Good and evil|goodness]] itself, [[perfect]],{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1004.htm |title=''Summa'', I., Q.4 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109155637/http://newadvent.org/summa/1004.htm |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} [[Infinity|infinite]],{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1007.htm |title=''Summa'', I., Q.7 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109163652/http://newadvent.org/summa/1007.htm |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} [[omnipotent]],{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1025.htm#article3 |title=''Summa'', I., Q.25, art.3 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111121213839/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1025.htm#article3 |archivedate=21 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} omniscient, happiness itself,[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2003.htm#article1 ''Summa'', II-I, Q.3, art.1.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130312035235/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2003.htm |date=12 March 2013 }} "God is happiness by His Essence." knowledge itself, [[Agape|love]] itself, [[omnipresent]],{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1008.htm |title=''Summa'', I., Q.8 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109163509/http://newadvent.org/summa/1008.htm |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} [[Immutability (theology)|immutable]],{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1009.htm |title=''Summa'', I., Q.9 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109161542/http://newadvent.org/summa/1009.htm |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} and eternal.{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1010.htm#article2 |title=''Summa'', I., Q.10, art.2 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111128084320/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1010.htm#article2 |archivedate=28 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Summing up these properties, Aquinas offers the term ''[[actus purus]]'' (Latin: "pure actuality"). Aquinas held that not only does God have [[knowledge]] of everything,{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1014.htm |title=''Summa'', I, Q.14, arts. 5, 6, & 9 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109162047/http://newadvent.org/summa/1014.htm |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} but that God has "the most perfect knowledge," and that it is also true to say that God "is" His understanding.{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1014.htm |title=''Summa'', I, Q.14, art. 4 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109162047/http://newadvent.org/summa/1014.htm |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Aquinas also understands God as the transcendent cause of the universe, the "first Cause of all things, exceeding all things caused by Him," the source of all creaturely being and the cause of every other cause.Summa Theologiae I, Q. 12, art. 12. Consequently, God's causality is not like the causality of any other causes (all other causes are "secondary causes"), because He is the transcendent source of all being, causing and sustaining every other existing thing at every instant. Consequently, God's causality is never in competition with the causality of creatures; rather, God even causes some things through the causality of creatures.Summa Contra Gentiles III, chap. 17. Aquinas was an advocate of the "analogical way", which says that because God is infinite, people can only speak of God by analogy, for some of the aspects of the divine nature are hidden (''Deus absconditus'') and others revealed (''Deus revelatus'') to finite human minds. Thomist philosophy holds that we can know ''about'' God through his creation (general revelation), but only in an analogous manner.[http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/ContraGentiles1.htm#30 ''Summa contra Gentiles'', Bk. I, chp. 30.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228055614/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/ContraGentiles1.htm |date=28 February 2009 }} "For we cannot grasp what God is, but only what He is not and how other things are related to Him, as is clear from what we said above." For instance, we can speak of God's goodness only by understanding that goodness as applied to humans is similar to, but not identical with, the goodness of God. Further, he argues that [[sacred scripture]] employs [[figurative language]]: "Now it is natural to man to attain to intellectual truths through sensible objects, because all our knowledge originates from sense. Hence in Holy Writ, spiritual truths are fittingly taught under the ''likeness'' of material things."{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1001.htm#article9 |title=''Summa'', I, Q.1, art.9 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111123045429/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1001.htm#article9 |archivedate=23 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} In order to demonstrate God's creative power, Aquinas says: "If a being participates, to a certain degree, in an 'accident,' this accidental property must have been communicated to it by a cause which possesses it essentially. Thus iron becomes incandescent by the action of fire. Now, God is His own power which subsists by itself. The being which subsists by itself is necessarily one." == Anthropology == [[File:SummaTheologiae.jpg|thumb|''[[Summa Theologiæ]]'', Pars secunda, prima pars. (copy by Peter Schöffer, 1471)]] In addition to agreeing with the [[Aristotelianism|Aristotelian]] definition of man as "the [[rational animal]]," Aquinas also held various other beliefs about the [[Substance theory|substance]] of man. For instance, as the [[essence]] ([[Nature (philosophy)|nature]]) of all men are the same,[http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte&Essentia.htm ''De Ente et Essentia'', 24.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091126104033/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte%26Essentia.htm |date=26 November 2009 }} "It is clear, therefore, that the essence of man and the essence of [[Socrates]] do not differ, except as the non-designated from the designated. Whence [[Averroes|the Commentator]] says in his considerations on the seventh book of the ''[[Metaphysics (Aristotle)|Metaphysics]]'' that "Socrates is nothing other than animality and rationality, which are his ''[[quiddity]]''."" and the definition of being is "an essence that exists," humans that are real therefore only differ by their [[Category of being|specific qualities]]. More generally speaking, all beings of the same [[genus]] have the same essence, and so long as they exist, only differ by [[accident (philosophy)|accidents]] and [[substantial form]].[http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte&Essentia.htm ''De Ente et Essentia'', 33.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091126104033/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/DeEnte%26Essentia.htm |date=26 November 2009 }} "The difference, on the contrary, is a name taken from a determinate form, and taken in a determinate way, i.e. as not including a determinate matter in its meaning. This is clear, for example, when we say animated, i.e., that which has a soul; for what it is, whether a body or something other, is not expressed. Whence [[Avicenna|Ibn Sīnā]] says that the genus is not understood in the difference as a part of its essence, but only as something outside its essence, as the subject also is understood in its properties. And this is why the genus is not predicated essentially of the difference, as the Philosopher says in the third book of the Metaphysics and in the fourth book of the Topics, but only in the way in which a subject is predicated of its property." === Soul === Thomists define the soul as the substantial form of living beings.[http://dhspriory.org/thomas/DeAnima.htm St. Thomas Aquinas's commentary on ''De anima'', Bk. I, 402a1–403b2, §1.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100404042737/http://dhspriory.org/thomas/DeAnima.htm |date=4 April 2010 }} "Now living beings taken all together form a certain class of being; hence in studying them the first thing to do is to consider what living things have in common, and afterwards what each has peculiar to itself. What they have in common is a life-principle or soul; in this they are all alike. In conveying knowledge, therefore, about living things one must first convey it about the soul as that which is common to them all. Thus when Aristotle sets out to treat of living things, he begins with the soul; after which, in subsequent books, he defines the properties of particular living beings." Thus, plants have "vegetative souls," animals have "sensitive souls," while human beings alone have "intellectual" – rational and immortal – souls.{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1075.htm#article6 |title=''Summa'', I, Q.75, art.6 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119083516/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1075.htm#article6 |archivedate=19 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }} {{quote|For Aristotle, the soul is one, but endowed with five groups of faculties (''dunámeis''): (1) the "vegetative" faculty (''threptikón''), concerned with the maintenance and development of organic life; (2) the appetite (''oretikón''), or the tendency to any good; (3) the faculty of sense perception (''aisthetikón''); (4) the "locomotive" faculty (''kinetikón''), which presides over the various bodily movements; and (5) reason (''dianoetikón''). The [[Scholasticism|Scholastics]] generally follow Aristotle's classification. For them body and soul are united in one complete substance. The soul is the ''forma substantialis'', the vital principle, the source of all activities. Hence their science of the soul deals with functions which nowadays belong to the provinces of biology and physiology. [...] The nature of the mind and its relations to the organism are questions that belong to philosophy or metaphysics.|[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/05749a.htm Dubray, C. (1909). Faculties of the Soul. In ''The Catholic Encyclopedia''. New York: Robert Appleton Company. Retrieved May 29, 2010 from New Advent.]}} The appetite of man has two parts, rational and irrational. The rational part is called the will, and the irrational part is called passion. === Ethics === Aquinas affirms Aristotle's definition of happiness as "an operation according to perfect [[virtue]]",{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2003.htm#article2 |title=''Summa'', II-I, Q.3, art.2 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120109063700/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2003.htm#article2 |archivedate=9 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }}[http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/Ethics1.htm#10 St. Thomas Aquinas's commentary on ''Nicomachean Ethics'', Lec. 10, §130.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924060713/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/Ethics1.htm |date=24 September 2015 }} Aquinas further says that "it is clear that happiness is a virtue-oriented activity proper to man in a complete life." and that "happiness is called man's supreme good, because it is the attainment or enjoyment of the supreme good."{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2003.htm#article1 |title=''Summa'', II-I, Q.3, art.1 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120109063700/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2003.htm#article1 |archivedate=9 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }} Regarding what the virtues are, Aquinas ascertained the [[cardinal virtues]] to be [[prudence]], [[Temperance (virtue)|temperance]], [[justice]], and [[Cardinal virtues|fortitude]]. The cardinal virtues are natural and revealed in nature, and they are binding on everyone. There are, however, three [[theological virtues]]: [[faith]], [[hope]], and [[Charity (virtue)|charity]] (which is used interchangeably with love in the sense of ''[[agape]]''). These are [[supernatural]] and are distinct from other virtues in their object, namely, God.{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2062.htm#article2 |title=''Summa'', II-I, Q.62, art.2 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109214542/http://newadvent.org/summa/2062.htm#article2 |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} In accordance with [[Roman Catholic theology]], Aquinas argues that humans can neither wish nor do [[Good and evil|good]] without [[Grace (Christianity)#Grace in Catholicism|divine grace]].{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2109.htm#article2 |title=''Summa'', II-I, Q.109, art.2 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111113214919/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2109.htm#article2 |archivedate=13 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} However, "doing good" here refers to doing good per se: man ''can'' do, moved by God even then but "only" in the sense in which even his nature depends on God's moving, things that happen to be good in some respect, and are not sinful, though if he has not grace, it will be without merit, and he will not succeed in it all the time. Therefore, happiness is attained through the perseverance of virtue given by the Grace of God,{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2109.htm#article10 |title=''Summa'', II-I, Q. 109, art.10 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111113214919/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2109.htm#article10 |archivedate=13 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} which is not fully attained on earth;[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2005.htm#article3 ''Summa'', II-I, Q.5, art.3.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021152708/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2005.htm |date=21 October 2012 }} "First, from the general notion of happiness. For since happiness is a "perfect and sufficient good," it excludes every evil, and fulfils every desire. But in this life every evil cannot be excluded." only at the [[beatific vision]].[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2005.htm#article1 ''Summa'', II-I, Q.5, art.1.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021152708/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2005.htm |date=21 October 2012 }} "Happiness is the attainment of the Perfect Good... And therefore man can attain Happiness. This can be proved again from the fact that man is capable of seeing God, [which] man's perfect Happiness consists."{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/5093.htm#article1 |title=''Summa'', supp., Q.93, art.1 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111115002919/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/5093.htm#article1 |archivedate=15 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Notably, man cannot attain true happiness without God.{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2005.htm#article5 |title=''Summa'', II-I, Q.5, art.5 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109213956/http://newadvent.org/summa/2005.htm#article5 |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Regarding [[emotion]] (used synonymously with the word "passion" in this context), which, following [[John Damascene]],{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2022.htm#article3 |title=''Summa'', II-I, Q.22, art.3 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no when we imagine good or evil," Thomism repudiates both the [[Epicurean]] view that happiness consists in [[pleasure]] (sensual experiences that invoke positive emotion),{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2034.htm#article2 |title=''Summa'', II-I, Q.34., art.2 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111128084650/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2034.htm#article2 |archivedate=28 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2002.htm#article6 |title=''Summa'', II-I, Q.2, art.6 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111204143359/http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2002.htm#article6 |archivedate=4 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }} and the [[Stoicism|Stoic]] view that emotions are vices by nature.{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2024.htm#article2 |title=''Summa'', II-I, Q.24, art.2 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109215138/http://newadvent.org/summa/2024.htm#article2 |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Aquinas takes a moderate view of emotion, quoting Augustine: "They are evil if our love is evil; good if our love is good."{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2024.htm#article1 |title=''Summa'', II-I, Q.24, art.1 |publisher=Newadvent.org |accessdate=20 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109215138/http://newadvent.org/summa/2024.htm#article1 |archivedate=9 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} While most emotions are morally neutral, some are inherently virtuous (e.g. pity){{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2024.htm#article4 |title=''Summa'', II-I, Q.24, art.4 |publisher=Newadvent.org
